description-en: A female Hindu devotee is performing Aarti/Puja by looking at the moon through the silhouette of a window. A basket of flowers stands in the window frame. In the background, the silhouettes of large temples with palm trees can be seen. Woman smiles happily and wears make-up: cayol and lipstick.

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In its simplest form, a pert young woman holds aloft a puja tray with two oil lamps and flower petals. She stands inside an archway that looks out into a nighttime sky with crescent moon and a silhouetted outline of South Indian temple towers on the horizon. The viewer does not know who this worshiper is, and it is not clear to whom or what she is making her offerings. She looks happily upwards, perhaps to the tray itself. The anonymous poster artist has given here a generic illustration of the pleasure of puja. (Richard H. Davis) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Not limiting themselves to offering images for worship, poster artists have also sought to create images of worship. The phrases here are adapted from the “model of/model for” formulation for the definition of religion, coined by the late anthropologist Clifford Geertz. The Priya Paul Collection contains a number of fine poster images depicting the act of puja. (Richard H. Davis) (gs)
